name: South Hall
text: South Hall was the second building constructed on campus in 1855 and it was previously the UW Madison Normal Department. The Normal Department admitted the first group of women to the school in 1863 which included 76 of them and saw 6 of them graduate in 1865, becoming the first female graduates of UW Madison.
direction: Begin your tour at South Hall

name: Chadbourne Hall
text: Chadbourne Hall, previously known as Ladies Hall, was the first female dormitory on campus. It was built to segregate men and women as Dr. Chadbourne believed women were a distraction to men. The building was used as a place for women to live and study. Following the departure of Dr Chadbourne, education became desegregated and it was then solely used as a women's dormitory.
direction: Head down Bascom Hill and make a right when you reach N Park St

name: Van Hise Hall
text: President Van Hise developed "The Wisconsin Idea", a concept where he believed that education should be provided to all people, allowing them to tackle all issues thay they may face. In his terms, "I shall never be content until the beneficient influence of the University reaches every family in the state". "The Wisconsin Idea" still exists on campus and governs ....

name: College Library
text: College Library is home to the English department at UW Madison and in 1918, Mabel Watson Raimey was the first African American women to graduate from UW Madison with a bachelors degree in English. She went on to become the first African American women to practice law in Wisconsin.

name: North Hall
text: North Hall, the first building erected on campus, was home to Kathryn Clarenbach's faculty office when she worked for the university. Clarenbach, a graduate of UW Madison, was the chairman of the Governor's Comission on the Status of Women and was a co-founder of the National Organization for Women (NOW) which hosted meetings at her office in the North Hall.

name: Bascom Hall
text: Bascom Hall is the iconic infrastructure that sits atop of Bascom Hill and overlooks State Street that leads to the Wisconsin State Capitol. This building houses the office of the Chancellor for the university and the first ever female Chancellor, Donna Shalala, led the school from 1988 to 1993. She developed the Madison Plan which pushed to recruit and hire more minorities on campus.

name: Sterling Hall
text: Congratulations! You are at the last stop of the tour - Sterling Hall. Sterling Hall is home to the Gender and Women's Studies (GWS) department at UW Madison which was established in 1975. It also consists of the Center for Research on Gender and Women which was founded in 1977. Currently, the department offers over 40 courses for undergraduate and graduate students. GWS is offered as a major, a certificate, a graduate program and a PhD program.
